``Forbidden Sun'' (Academy Entertainment. VHS-Beta, $79.95. Rated R)
Lauren Hutton plays a former Olympic athlete who runs a summer school for girl gymnasts on the island of Crete. Among her pupils is Jane, a juvenile delinquent who wants to emulate the ancients Greeks and vault over the horns of a live bull. When one of the girls is raped, Jane uses a variation of the ``bull dance'' to get revenge. Uh huh, this film is as lame as it sounds. The suspense lasts about as long as a skip across the balance beam. The payoff at the end is meager. Filled with references to arson, bulls, rape and young women, ``Forbidden Sun'' undoubtedly has some kind of psychosexual subtext, but don't waste your time trying to find it. By Pete Brown, Associated Press Writer.

``Great Balls of Fire'' (Orion Home Video. VHS-Beta, $89.98. Rated PG-13)
Some of the best movie biographies are films such as ``Lawrence of Arabia,'' ``Gandhi'' and ``Raging Bull,'' all carefully researched and written and based on a variety of sources. And with such standard-bearers, why does Hollywood continue to seek out books, usually best sellers, that give only a fragmented (and sometimes biased) account of an event or life, and rush to make movies of them? Are the creative minds of the film industry incapable of doing original research and stories? These questions come to mind with ``Great Balls of Fire,'' Jim McBride's movie on the life and times of the piano-pumping rocker Jerry Lee Lewis, based on the book by Myra Lewis with Murray Silver. McBride and Jack Baran did the screenplay. The movie is a kinetic romp through the early years of rock 'n' roll, when Elvis was King and pretenders like Jerry Lee threatened to topple him. The music is non-stop fun, whether songs by Presley and Lewis, or Gene Autry singing ``Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer'' or Dave ``Baby'' Cortez stomping through ``Happy Organ.'' Dennis Quaid is a treat as Lewis. He's manic, lewd, adorable and crazy. He swaggers about with childish abandon, and dances with the piano like a careless lover. At times, though, Quaid becomes almost cartoonish in his portrayal. But that's OK, because Jerry Lee Lewis was a walking comic book. Myra (Winona Ryder) was Jerry Lee's third wife. She also was his third cousin and 13 years old when they married. He was 22. Ryder (``Heathers'') continues to impress with her film work. She is a great casting choice for the pubescent, pulchritudinous bubble gum-chewing Myra. She is wide-eyed and dreamy-eyed, giggly and pouty, lusty and innocent. Their wedding scene is a wonderful slice of life. Ryder stares blankly at the justice of the peace, mouth ajar like he's the purple people eater. Later, at the dinner table with her parents, she bursts into giggles knowing that she's married and they haven't a clue. The year was 1958, and Lewis had already shot to the top of the charts with ``Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On'' and ``Great Balls of Fire.'' But his marriage to Myra shocked a staid post-war public, and Lewis' career crumbled. The movie is centered on Myra and Jerry Lee's relationship (it should have been titled ``Jerry and Myra'') and abruptly ends with the birth of their son, Steve Allen, who drowned in a swimming pool when he was 3. The late Trey Wilson co-stars as Sam Phillips, whose Sun Records launched Presley and others.Alec Baldwin is deliciously self-righteous as Lewis' cousin and boyhood buddy, TV evangelist Jimmy Swaggart. ``Great Balls of Fire'' is a harmless piece of entertainment for a Saturday afternoon. It's fun to watch, especially Quaid's gymnastics and clownish grimaces. But the movie lacks authenticity; it seems to be laughing at itself and at the era it purports to chronicle. There's also an element of racism. A scene at a black nightspot, for example, depicts black patrons as lewd animals doing bumps and grinds, and crawling over each other in the most suggestive ways. By Dolores Barclay, AP Arts Editor.
